thread.title_full: Dortmund could face £85k fine and closure of stand | Daily Mail Online

author: Reuters
title: Dortmund could face £85k fine and closure of stand
text:
The German football association (DFB) on Friday demanded a one-match ban for Borussia Dortmund fans from their south stand and a 100,000 euro (£85,000) fine after crowd trouble in several games including last week's win over RB Leipzig.
The DFB's control committee said it had proposed the stand closure and fine given that Dortmund were repeat offenders and had received a suspended sentence last July for similar problems.
Fans last week unfurled banners attacking Leipzig, owned by energy drink makers Red Bull, as well as their sports director Ralf Rangnick and Red Bull owner Dieter Mateschitz.
Some of the banners held up by Borussia Dortmund fans during last Saturday's 1-0 win over RB Leipzig at the Signal Iduna Park - the club could face a heavy fine and stand closure
Dortmund could be fine £85,000 by the German FA and their south stand could be closed
The Dortmund players line up to salute their fans following the 1-0 win over Leipzig last week
'Slaughter the bulls,' read one, 'Beer instead of soda' read another in reference to Leipzig's owner.
Dortmund fans lit flares during the game, while outside the 80,000-seat stadium some fans attacked arriving Leipzig supporters. They had also caused trouble in three other matches this season, the DFB said.
Dortmund won the Leipzig game, but club bosses repeatedly apologised to Leipzig for their fans' behaviour.
Some Dortmund fans apologised to Leipzig for the violence and offensive messages during their midweek German Cup fixture with Hertha Berlin
Banners reading 'No to violence' condemned their own fans' actions in attacking Leipzig fans
'Such a defamation of individuals or clubs by using banners and chants is unacceptable and needs to be sanctioned,' said Anton Nachreiner, head of the DFB committee. 'The same goes for the flares'.
The south stand, nicknamed the 'Yellow Wall', is the largest standing stand in Europe with a 25,000 capacity.
Dortmund have until Monday to either accept the proposal or reject it in which case the decision will be taken by FA's sports court.
